document.title: Texas Essential Knowledge and Skills for Science

F4B1BCDA78AB41E189CB21478B86E143.description: demonstrate an awareness of new developments and discoveries in astronomy.

978E40AEF5AA45B88572511A42379659.description: recognize the importance of space telescopes to the collection of astronomical data across the electromagnetic spectrum;

DA1B94804A61425CAD88206C0F2C3319.description: analyze the importance of ground-based technology in astronomical studies;

9016D45B282B4E01A52289C2422CE1EC.description: recognize the advancement of knowledge in astronomy through robotic space flight;

1B6FD767C2E248E1A65DDA48C53837E4.description: identify and explain the contributions of human space flight and future plans and challenges;

8515150195AA41E9BF106A07E31DC1AA.description: Science concepts. The student recognizes the benefits and challenges of space exploration to the study of the universe. The student is expected to:

335940D401344AA9986E40F1DEDFB108.description: research and describe scientific hypotheses of the fate of the universe, including open and closed universes and the role of dark matter and dark energy.

BB2F884D16E941498FA6B45F48C9012B.description: research and describe current theories of the evolution of the universe, including estimates for the age of the universe;

CDC5FCE2DAB1424AB51681F06C45BBD3.description: research and describe the historical development of the Big Bang Theory, including red shift, cosmic microwave background radiation, and other supporting evidence;

42F1B37F862149E39B443018E1DB513B.description: Science concepts. The student knows the scientific theories of cosmology. The student is expected to:

956E8874E5A6413BB04A81EE6F20835E.description: compare and contrast the different types of galaxies, including spiral, elliptical, irregular, and dwarf.

DB2FE68402B54201A8DFA0B0F7CFE717.description: recognize the type, structure, and components of our Milky Way galaxy and location of our solar system within it;

7D6D051037884FFE83E9D7E2E0F039E7.description: Science concepts. The student knows the variety and properties of galaxies. The student is expected to:

73D43DE730244DF5BB8AA17257C39393.description: use the Hertzsprung-Russell diagram to plot and examine the life cycle of stars from birth to death.

81FDF235A5E94E00814AB09F9758BD13.description: relate the use of spectroscopy in obtaining physical data on celestial objects such as temperature, chemical composition, and relative motion;

FF1070128058463E8417C05E31B776EF.description: compare how the mass and gravity of a main sequence star will determine its end state as a white dwarf, neutron star, or black hole;

B4BA66200B6F41D78BCD8461289A81BF.description: differentiate among the end states of stars, including white dwarfs, neutron stars, and black holes;

0723FC6AA6724AF5BC7A6CF30B875C71.description: evaluate the relationship between mass and fusion on the dying process and properties of stars;

3D46AC0E5E5248308F218A1DBBF035F9.description: characterize star formation in stellar nurseries from giant molecular clouds, to protostars, to the development of main sequence stars;

4EA8BD8497454C6D8283A4B8FE29B326.description: identify the characteristics of main sequence stars, including surface temperature, age, relative size, and composition;

7B1A7817CADA40BB8785A63905F46AB6.description: Science concepts. The student knows the characteristics and life cycle of stars. The student is expected to:

7AE853F546304D1C8D53E5787A85FDB1.description: analyze solar magnetic storm activity, including coronal mass ejections, prominences, flares, and sunspots.

90D95E1F02C5481CB7ED68027E42B05E.description: describe the eleven-year solar cycle and the significance of sunspots;

C7D752B65CAA4C5C99CF0B7899DFCF31.description: distinguish between nuclear fusion and nuclear fission, and identify the source of energy within the Sun as nuclear fusion of hydrogen to helium;

BCCE21AEF6984FA78DF304936783AEA5.description: identify the approximate mass, size, motion, temperature, structure, and composition of the Sun;

171383B6273D4CA38BD0BA5BDDE94BBC.description: Science concepts. The student knows the role of the Sun as the star in our solar system. The student is expected to:

E7BAFCA1EF694406B3DBF2F61E072C61.description: explore the origins and significance of small solar system bodies, including asteroids, comets, and Kuiper belt objects.

20A64BFA73FB4962B90F5260AC906287.description: relate the role of Newton's law of universal gravitation to the motion of the planets around the Sun and to the motion of natural and artificial satellites around the planets;

070B981FB5AF4E3AACE5C4B5019EC7F4.description: compare the planets in terms of orbit, size, composition, rotation, atmosphere, natural satellites, and geological activity;

3BC0C80E282347F1B3E18D450D2E6C45.description: compare and contrast the factors essential to life on Earth such as temperature, water, mass, and gases to conditions on other planets;

E3555648C9F34E939010F733EF6B6A62.description: Science concepts. The student knows that planets of different size, composition, and surface features orbit around the Sun. The student is expected to:

4E6759F4C1A24384919A46D720DC8345.description: examine the relationship of the seasons to equinoxes, solstices, the tropics, and the equator.

C481781DAD2A48AAACA069A903466407.description: recognize that the angle of incidence of sunlight determines the concentration of solar energy received on Earth at a particular location;

57F885D314424386AE0A5AECB17A47BD.description: explain how latitudinal position affects the length of day and night throughout the year;

BE17193DD21A4C7FB9CA67BC0C6C8006.description: recognize that seasons are caused by the tilt of Earth's axis;

F27A84B3101D4D65A1E9F121D9E7E324.description: Science concepts. The student knows the reasons for the seasons. The student is expected to:

3D0D23CECF0E4E1F9221A5E686CB4120.description: identify the effects of the Moon on tides.

1EC63756971F4C4A8C325334C12B892B.description: identify and differentiate the causes of lunar and solar eclipses, including differentiating between lunar phases and eclipses;

DA26ED7AAB574766BA68EDBC3D1BCFE7.description: illustrate the cause of lunar phases by showing positions of the Moon relative to Earth and the Sun for each phase, including new moon, waxing crescent, first quarter, waxing gibbous, full moon, waning gibbous, third quarter, and waning crescent;

DA4CBF4F27B04301A1CA029B76D257B8.description: observe and record data about lunar phases and use that information to model the Sun, Earth, and Moon system;

284A654E6A2C41639F3570FA531ED31D.description: Science concepts. The student knows the role of the Moon in the Sun, Earth, and Moon system. The student is expected to:

7ADD1608AD3C495DAEFAB2CECBD187AF.description: demonstrate the use of units of measurement in astronomy, including Astronomical Units and light years.

3F4418ABBEED4A458D1CA764C961F878.description: relate apparent versus absolute magnitude to the distances of celestial objects;

21987D6E6D63436281A5032EBDA8C3D2.description: examine the scale, size, and distance of the stars, Milky Way, and other galaxies through the use of data and modeling;

BBCE30EE1694489693D1DA638E96921D.description: compare and contrast the scale, size, and distance of objects in the solar system such as the Sun and planets through the use of data and modeling;

E30F95BB46E54747B858AAA7AEC72B5F.description: compare and contrast the scale, size, and distance of the Sun, Earth, and Moon system through the use of data and modeling;

6717A54FF3944885A05D33A7CC42D440.description: Science concepts. The student knows our place in space. The student is expected to:

AA7D855B5CD34248B33AFEAFBB34E2A4.description: recognize and identify constellations such as Ursa Major, Ursa Minor, Orion, Cassiopeia, and constellations of the zodiac.

D973F3A77E8F4D96AD993D9225037AE8.description: observe and record the apparent movement of the Moon, planets, and stars in the nighttime sky;

414FE0D840734CADA0ECCC7F13A2A3AA.description: observe and record the apparent movement of the Sun and Moon during the day;

FE4F77B700F6421BAA52F46250B9F4F4.description: Science concepts. The student develops a familiarity with the sky. The student is expected to:

D5B4C5E9F5514F9EBF70ADE894017366.description: explain the contributions of modern astronomy to today's society, including the identification of potential asteroid/comet impact hazards and the Sun's effects on communication, navigation, and high-tech devices.

55F20E3C7A564A9CA497F69CF144D62C.description: describe and explain the historical origins of the perceived patterns of constellations and the role of constellations in ancient and modern navigation;

670CDD7F08C44BBBA518C340A79CF062.description: research and describe the contributions of scientists to our changing understanding of astronomy, including Ptolemy, Copernicus, Tycho Brahe, Kepler, Galileo, Newton, Einstein, and Hubble, and the contribution of women astronomers, including Maria Mitchell and Henrietta Swan Leavitt;

C8EA4211B1124FA2BE756053254576A6.description: research and describe the use of astronomy in ancient civilizations such as the Egyptians, Mayans, Aztecs, Europeans, and the native Americans;

3D82562482984E07A878D2A24F4ED91F.description: Science concepts. The student recognizes the importance and uses of astronomy in civilization. The student is expected to:

CBC16669B42D4925A83D96F2CB065F06.description: describe the connection between astronomy and future careers.

B26CD5E8683740A8B6A2E87B6884076C.description: evaluate the impact of research on scientific thought, society, and the environment;

D888FD85C1384134BF802B2DD55DA227.description: draw inferences based on data related to promotional materials for products and services;

0984EC27B2D14C3EAA49592A61E7586E.description: communicate and apply scientific information extracted from various sources such as current events, news reports, published journal articles, and marketing materials;

2E4298B23D8F4D2EA3D2A2DBBF1A5863.description: in all fields of science, analyze, evaluate, and critique scientific explanations by using empirical evidence, logical reasoning, and experimental and observational testing, including examining all sides of scientific evidence of those scientific explanations, so as to encourage critical thinking by the student;

3386779BF5B84B4C9691CAFAA075F295.description: Scientific processes. The student uses critical thinking, scientific reasoning, and problem solving to make informed decisions within and outside the classroom. The student is expected to:

7CCDB53C676A48EF8F5BB46E39456998.description: use astronomical technology such as telescopes, binoculars, sextants, computers, and software.

D0C3FF35A9BA4D3F9EF42599D5302D40.description: communicate valid conclusions in writing, oral presentations, and through collaborative projects;

197A6C3E21A24E11A465CD678F105233.description: organize, analyze, evaluate, make inferences, and predict trends from data, including making new revised hypotheses when appropriate;

8919E4175AA54EC4B7E6BCE4FCEF68AC.description: collect data and make measurements with accuracy and precision;

65C44A8EAA954089ACB296EC5DB7D7BA.description: plan and implement investigative procedures, including making observations, asking questions, formulating testable hypotheses, and selecting equipment and technology;

B6ECCB8BC0474A29AC8166C59BE2C7B4.description: distinguish between scientific hypotheses and scientific theories;

C0AD5D0AF16B4A4FAABD4BC92666ADF9.description: know that scientific theories are based on natural and physical phenomena and are capable of being tested by multiple independent researchers. Unlike hypotheses, scientific theories are well-established and highly-reliable explanations, but may be subject to change as new areas of science and new technologies are developed;

0CF90E1B001746AEBDFDDA45B18CEC49.description: know that scientific hypotheses are tentative and testable statements that must be capable of being supported or not supported by observational evidence. Hypotheses of durable explanatory power which have been tested over a wide variety of conditions are incorporated into theories;

F7E3738CA4904DDD942A555D0B242D9D.description: know the definition of science and understand that it has limitations, as specified in subsection (b)(2) of this section;

C63B184AB55F45308615F12EA57F42CB.description: Scientific processes. The student uses scientific methods during laboratory and field investigations. The student is expected to:

BA041DC0F607440B97E96BD62DD2DD13.description: demonstrate an understanding of the use and conservation of resources and the proper disposal or recycling of materials.

265872073EC2456897834B9E4AE611FA.description: demonstrate safe practices during laboratory and field investigations;

861B5E79288A441C97B93F50999C2281.description: Scientific processes. The student, for at least 40% of instructional time, conducts laboratory and field investigations using safe, environmentally appropriate, and ethical practices. The student is expected to:

9A8EA21507A44F15AD66C7BC4959E58F.description: Scientific systems. A system is a collection of cycles, structures, and processes that interact. All systems have basic properties that can be described in terms of space, time, energy, and matter. Change and constancy occur in systems as patterns and can be observed, measured, and modeled. These patterns help to make predictions that can be scientifically tested. Students should analyze a system in terms of its components and how these components relate to each other, to the whole, and to the external environment.

072BEA2C952344CFB7404234E4B0120A.description: Science and social ethics. Scientific decision making is a way of answering questions about the natural world. Students should be able to distinguish between scientific decision-making methods and ethical and social decisions that involve the application of scientific information.

D2F53A82EF34446D8A37D4866E1F8615.description: Scientific inquiry. Scientific inquiry is the planned and deliberate investigation of the natural world. Scientific methods of investigation can be experimental, descriptive, or comparative. The method chosen should be appropriate to the question being asked.

91EBF89F40454F7D91C5EAD09E1B0934.description: Nature of science. Science, as defined by the National Academy of Sciences, is the "use of evidence to construct testable explanations and predictions of natural phenomena, as well as the knowledge generated through this process." This vast body of changing and increasing knowledge is described by physical, mathematical, and conceptual models. Students should know that some questions are outside the realm of science because they deal with phenomena that are not scientifically testable.

D788EFFEDFA940C88863E6898FB731BB.description: Astronomy. In Astronomy, students conduct laboratory and field investigations, use scientific methods, and make informed decisions using critical thinking and scientific problem solving. Students study the following topics: astronomy in civilization, patterns and objects in the sky, our place in space, the moon, reasons for the seasons, planets, the sun, stars, galaxies, cosmology, and space exploration. Students who successfully complete Astronomy will acquire knowledge within a conceptual framework, conduct observations of the sky, work collaboratively, and develop critical-thinking skills.

6909B58A315A4171BFDDCEE46E954D59.description: General requirements. Students shall be awarded one credit for successful completion of this course. Suggested prerequisite: one unit of high school science. This course is recommended for students in Grade 11 or 12.
